replies.msg: ä¸éé›»è»Šè²»ä¿‚fixå·¦æ¯æ—¥å¤§ç´„100HKDå·¦å³, å…¶å¯¦æˆ‘ä½é‚Š, ä½¢éƒ½ä¿‚æ¯”å‘¢ç­†éŒ¢æˆ‘, ç´”ç²¹çœŸä¿‚ä½¢è¦ºå¾—å””è¿‘è¦‹å®¢å€‹åˆ° è¦ºå¾—é–“é…’åº—å””å¥½

Holidaying in tokyo this autumn is a safe bet since the yen has dropped fairly rapidly over the past four months. The sun has been dazzlingly bright so you may just as well have a good long soak in an outdoor onsen soaking up the sun. In fact I've just got out of an onsen and am drying myself on a towelğŸ˜ŠThere's a pageant of which the final round will take place in tokyo next month. I would imagine Aiko seems quite likely to enter the final round. My friend alex has received a commission to compose a waltz for the pageant as one of the contestants will be showcasing her waltz dance which we all can't wait to see. I would like to express my congratulations to him for having accepted a commission for a waltz since it's a rare opportunity. I should also like to extend my heartfelt congratulations to my friend Fumi on progressing through the preliminary round. She's a contestant in the beauty contest and I won't be surprised if she professes through the semifinal. I remember a decade ago there was a protest where the protestors clashed with the police in Osaka. I saw it on NHK then. i thought the police weren't tough enough. All the riot police were holding a truncheon in one hand and a shield in the other hand. In this way you can't really fight the protestors and arrest them since you have no free hands to grab hold of them. Thats why it took four policemen to get hold of one protestor..From a fighting angle some of the police should be holding just a shield, some just a baton, the other both. And all of them should be trained on how they fight when they're holding just a shield, holding just a baton and holding both. It was a disaster. I didn't think osaka had ever been so chaotic before. The police who i wholeheartedly support only used tear smoke in an attempt to disperse the protestors which was closely not enough. The police shouldn't have been afraid of being criticized for using excessive force because this was utterly not the case. Firing rubber bullets and bean bags at the demonstrators was necessary, lawful and appropriate. Those who sabotaged the nearby buildings and the railings should've been sent to jail. The train network was paralyzed by the strikes for many weeks. The united states had already imposed trade sanctions on Japan at that time. The then US president said he would take punitive action against Japan if the police there used excessive force. Japan was afraid that America would toughen punitive import tariffs still further on agricultural products, food, clothes and alcohol and worse still they would convince the other nations to impose international economic sanctions against the country. Of course the downside was the costs of the products in America which they had imposed import duties on would rise still higher. The economic sanctions against japan wouldn't be dropped until the then united states president's term of office expired two years later. The next day everybody was warned of the danger of violent clashes only to find that it was a false alarm. There were half as many people in the street. However as long as you followed the news and stayed away from places where there were demonstrations, osaka was safe. In the same evening a bus crash killed nineteen passengers. Detectives assigned the blame for the accident to a hailstorm and a heavy snowfalls- then a brutal murder took place in the capital. Detectives assigned hatred as the motive for the horrendous crime.
